description:
First though, another film that defies neat definition, Trash. It's set in Rio de Janeiro where kids picking over rubbish on one of the city's dumps find a wallet. Its contents lead them into dangerous intrigue with corrupt police, old injustice and plenty of action around the city from shanty towns to swanky suburbs. So it's a story with dialogue mainly in subtitle Portuguese for young people. Yet it has themes familiar from gritty gangster films like City of God. The director Stephen Daldry had worked with young actors before, most famously with the film and stage show Billy Elliot. For Trash, he chose some big-name stars like Martin Sheen, but made the crucial decision when it came to the children to cast for real-life experience rather than technique.

"We guessed in the end it would be, nonprofessionals will be the main protagonists and main leads in the film, because it's about three kids who live on a landfill site and work on a landfill site as recyclers. And the challenge felt so extraordinary, we've eventually found the kids we want to work with and then many more months putting them through process of trying to understand what the story might be. The kids in the end we chose had never been to a cinema. But most of the time, it was really listening to them about the story they wanted to tell. So we just gave them the, the really beginnings of what the story might be. It's sort of the venture, treasure hunt really. It's some sort of fantasy film. But what was important to us was making the film make sense to them, knowing that actually in the end the film would have to be improvised."
